titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Stanford University Postcard Collection

publicationstmt.publisher: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on .

did.head: Overview

physdesc.label: Physical Description:
physdesc.extent: 1.5 Linear Feet Approximately 1149 items in 5 boxes

did.abstract: Collection depicts Stanford University buildings, grounds, and people; subjects include athletics and athletic facilities, student amusements, the cactus garden, old chemistry building, dormitories, fraternity and sorority houses, views of the Quad and Inner Quad, Lake Lagunita, libraries, Stanford mausoleum, Memorial Arch, Memorial Church, museum, the Palo Alto tree, university workers (primarily images of horse-drawn wagons), David Starr Jordan, Domenico Grosso ("the Stanford hermit"), and the presidential installation of John C. Branner. A number of items depict damage to buildings from the 1906 earthquake. There are also a few items depicting Palo Alto and surrounding communities.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

accessrestrict.head: Information about Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research use.

userestrict.head: Ownership & Copyright
userestrict.p: All requests to reproduce, publish, quote from, or otherwise use collection materials must be submitted in writing to the Head of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, California 94304-6064. Consent is given on behalf of Special Collections as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission from the copyright owner. Such permission must be obtained from the copyright owner, heir(s) or assigns. See: http://library.stanford.edu/depts/spc/pubserv/permissions.html.
Restrictions also apply to digital representations of the original materials. Use of digital files is restricted to research and educational purposes.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: [identification of item], Stanford University Postcard Collection (PC0078). Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection depicts Stanford University buildings, grounds, and people; subjects include athletics and athletic facilities, student amusements, the cactus garden, old chemistry building, dormitories, fraternity and sorority houses, views of the Quad and Inner Quad, Lake Lagunita, libraries, Stanford mausoleum, Memorial Arch, Memorial Church, museum, the Palo Alto tree, university workers (primarily images of horse-drawn wagons), David Starr Jordan, Domenico Grosso ("the Stanford hermit"), and the presidential installation of John C. Branner. A number of items depict damage to buildings from the 1906 earthquake. There are also a few items depicting Palo Alto and surrounding communities.

scopecontent.p: Caption: reverse: The Stanford band outlines its unnatural axe at the 1972 Rose Bowl, in a tribute to the traditional symbol of Stanford athletic endeavor. This formation remains one of the few traditional segments of the otherwise contemporary and spirited Leland Stanford Junior University Marching Band shows.
Message: note: Stanford - California Game / Stanford turf, November 8, 1913
Message: This is the bunch that is going to do the work tomorrow. I am going to run the 2-mile again and believe me, its going to be a fast one, too! I'll do it or bust. Best wishes George

did.unittitle: Track team and coach in front of brick building

scopecontent.p: Message: Dear Uncle Herman, Received letter and several papers of you and have been trying to get a letter back at you but just now is the beginning of another siege of exams. On reverse of this is a picture of Stanford Track Team just before meet with U. Cal. Will write again next week. Sincerely, George
Message: note: The Freshman Team. Oct. 15, 1910. Hall made the only score for Stanford. the score was 3 to 3.
Message: These are the boys that will come thru next Sat. even if we did lose to-day. FER. to: L.J. Rehm

scopecontent.p: Message: Dear Rubie - This is a view of the cacus gardens near the Mausoleum. ... It's suffocatingly warm here & there isn't a bit of cold water on the place so we have to walk to Palo Alto to get a cold drink. Monday night the Encina boys gave their "night shirt" parade all over the Quad & it surely was funny. [more] to Ruby Durgin from Bel

Message: Dearr Mother, We received the box this afternoon. Olga was just needing the things. Aunt Lucy says to thank you for the band. We haven't said anything about going home yet but I want to come Sunday. We just went shopping in Palo Alto. Spent seventy cents. Love to you and Dad, Esther. to Mrs. E. E. Cleese

scopecontent.p: Caption: 862 - Encina Hall, Stanford University, California

Message: Hello Pete. Guess you're going to school by now. This is where I live. Haven't been hazed by the Sophs lately. Think my vacination is going to "take" & may have to drop foot-ball. Don't like this style as well as American anyway. Well, you folks let me hear from you some day. Bill to Wilford Allen Jr.
Caption: Geology and Engineering Buildings, Stanford

Message: Roble Hall, Oct. 25, 1911. Dear Henriette - I am having such a good time I don't know whether I will want to go home or not. . . . Had a walk around Dr. Jordan's house today. The girls are expecting you for the rally. Love to all, Auntie. to Henriette Thomas
Caption: 1904 Engineering Buildings, Stanford University, California

Message: Dear Amy-Just got your postal + sent you a message to come down but found that you have gone. Hope you have a nice trip--wish I was with you. Love from Ethan.

Message: Dear Friend--Just a line to hope that you are improving in strength each day. Were you able to get out to see any of the Admission Day festivities? I was so glad when it was over. Time flies so rapidly. Our ill folks are improving, and I sincerely hope you are. Much love, E.C.

Message: Dear Wilma, I am sending you a little birthday gift. I don't know whether you are at the same old place or not. Have not heard from you for weeks and weeks + more weeks. We have had a very pleasant summer the weather has been perfect. School started this a,m. so the children will be at the same old grind again. I'll tell the news when I answer your letter that I have not received yet. Love, Ida.
Caption: Hoover's Home Palo Alto, CA

scopecontent.p: Caption: President's House, Stanford University, CA

Message: This is Saturday and just a week ago we started on our walking trip which we certainly enjoyed. My sister didn't come that other Sunday but is coming down to-morrow, so Bil and I shall conduct anothe sight seeing expedition around Stanford. We had a fine boat ride on the Lake yesterday--one of the girls who can row took us out. Will you be at home next Saturday and could I come to see you then? The week after is our vacation and BIl and I are going to the City. Hazel
Caption: The Pines, Lagunita, Stanford University, Cal

Message: Glad to hear all the good news. Tell Grace a letter is coming--next mail I hope. It is partly written now. Muriel is dressmaker again. C. at work these two days. Weather cooler. Glad you get the Republican. Muting seems to promise well, from telephone messages. Hope you are all better sleepers now. Love from all, Mary.
Message: Hoping you had a pleasant journey and are looking forward to even pleasanter prospects in your work. W.

Message: (FRONT) This shows the ruins of the library--The city appears pretty badly shaken up even yet. (BACK) Sept. 12, '07. We are now on board the steamer "Hong Knog Maru" ready to start in about an hour. Had fine trip across continent. Nice day today. Love to all. Harriet & Willis.
Caption: Library, After the Earthquake, Palo Alto, Calif.
Message: Aug. 4, 1912, Palo Alto. Just spent a few hours here--Peru(?) is awful--temperature about 150 in the shade I think--Love, (--cut off--)

Message: Miira baby was born yest at. 4.oclock. a girl. Grandma is all smiles. Dad is at work here an the p. office running the hostes I guess that is what it is called. We havent heard from May yet. Mother.

Message: "it is perfectly grand, & I hope he takes me down sometime this year. I don't know whether I shall go there next year or not. At any rate I wont go to Mills. Julia agrees with me in this. How I wish I could go to Wellesley. It wouldn't be any more expensive than at Mills & the school is so much higher & has so much better standing, but it is so far off & so many girls apply that there would be no chance unless one applies two or three yrs. ahead the boys...(cut off from there)"

Message: "Hi! Left Lawsons at 12 & arrived at 9 pm. No trouble, beautiful trip weather nice, not to [sic] hot. Ruths place is sure nice, Called Marguerite to make a date & she has the mumps so that Trip is out. Going to Santa Cruz Sat. Saw Mary Whittaker. What a town, fraid I'd get lost if I were turned loose. Sure some beautiful homes here. Ruth has a lovely Magnolia tree in front yard. Lemon, Orang [sic], apple tree in back & grape vines all over the back fence. Will see you next week. Love 'Marie.'"
Imprint: San Jose Chamber of Commerce

Message: "10-25-35: Dear Mother. Just to let you know we are both well but very busy. We are going to move Nov. 6. Have been very busy getting ready. Business is also picking up. Geo. now has several good men. Hope this finds you feeling much better, Will write soon. Our address after Nov. 6 is 1101 Green Street, Apt 404. Much love from us both, Charlotte."

Message: I was very sorry not to see you while I was in Los Angeles for I wanted to tell you much about the glories of Stanford. It is the best place ever -- better than I thought it could be. Of course I'd never try to convince you for I know "a man convinced against his will is of the same opinion still" but just tell you about it. Sincerely, Frances M Hoyt. Stanford University -- Jan. 12, 1912

note.p: addressed to: Mr. Prentice Lebus, 1222 Bonnie Brae, Los Angeles, California

scopecontent.p: Caption: Stanford University - The J. Henry Meyer Memorial Libary at Stanford University bears the name of an early California businessman. Dedicated in 1966, it has a capacity of 140,000 volumes, arranged in open shelves according to undergraduate subject areas.

scopecontent.p: Caption: The "Palo Alto" Tree, Palo Alto, California. Under this Giant Redwood the "Palo Alto" Nov. 6th to 11th, 1769 - camped Portola and his band - the expedition that discovered San Francisco Bay. This was the assembling point for their reconnoitering parties. Other early explorers - De Anza, Vancover also used the tree as a landmark. Earlier, Indians held their council meetings here.
Caption: 5394 - The Famous Palo Alto Tree, Santa Clara Valley, California
Caption: Palo Alto California was named after this "Tall Tree" under which the Gaspar de Portola expedition camped November 6 - 11, 1769.

Message: This redwood tree is on the eastern edge of a ravine that's on the west side of Palo Alto, and is growing just beside, and on the north of the the Southern Pacific Railroad, which runs over a bridge over the ravine. Latitude:- Longitude:-

Message: Hello Frances:- Well I am back at Stanford at last. I brought the coon back with me, and she behaved fine. College starts on the 1st of September. This is rushing season now and I am pretty busy. I hope to see you soon. You had better run down here in a machine. All of the fellows went crazy over Pete. We turn her loose in the day time, and she has broken about every thing in the house but we don't care for that. my address is DTD House, Stanford University, Cal.

Message: Dearest Sis - Not one word have I heard from my sisters since leaving home. Esther had a letter from Henriette yesterday. she did not say how you were feeling. E and I went to the City Sat. to see the Blue Bird. I never saw anything more beautiful. glad to hear of Dorothy's success. The time is drawing near when I shall turn my face homeward. I wonder if I would ever be ready to go, feel as though I should like to stay on and on. The country is like a picture so green [illegible] I shall return Friday night. With much love. [illegible]

scopecontent.p: Caption: The Inner Quadrangle - Stanford University

Message: The "quad," as it is popularly called, is surrounded by twelve buildings and Memorial Church. It is an inner court some two hundred yards long and proportionally long wide. There are fourteen buildings in a square around the inner quad. All are joined by arcades. Then there are twelve buildings beside.(some 40 in all) [over]

The most expensive are Memorial Church, Chemistry building, Encina Hall for boys, New Library, New Gymnasium, Museum; some of which ar not yet finished. These six cost three of rouor million dollars. That is enought of itself to set up a small kindergarten isn't it? The other thirty-six buildings cost millions. Now if you wish to form big ideas of the wealth of the university - most of these buildings have been built of stone in the last ten years and only the interest on Stanford principal has been used. The principal remains untouched; only intrest is used for all purpose whatsoever.
